content.description:
Ninth Circle is a longer, exciting route with multiple betas and an assortment of different holds to keep even 5.12+ and up climbers engaged.

 Just be prepared for a possible blood sacrifice on the razor-sharp crimps with thin feet that make their way past the first two bolts (technical crux). Then, compose yourself for the next two slightly runout bolts--until permanent draws are added--by finding interesting beta made up of hidden holds, high feet, and/or big moves (mental crux). The rest of the climb certainly eases up by a letter grade or two, but features the more fun finger/hand pockets, slots, and cracks as you move diagonally to the left.  

 **The climb is still new so some fuzz could be cleaned with more ascents and some small holds may still blow. Wear a helmet.**
content.protection:
7 bolts to lower-off anchors.  

 Permadraw at bolt 4 is for ease in cleaning where the route take a left turn.
content.location: Walk up trail into the gutter and over the tree-bench across from Cherty Dancing. Walk forward a couple feet to large rocks and you will see a very short uphill trail to your left that leads to the base of the climb.

content.description:
The Constant Gardener is a short and wonderfully engaging slab with two crux sections - one just above bolt three and the second right before the chains.  

 Begin with a left facing layback flake and then use some pockets and juggy features to pull onto the slab proper.  Decipher a fun little problem with some good feet and sparse chert features before cruising your way to the final difficulties near the chain.  

 Once this climb has had a few dozen laps on it and the lichen fuzz is fully gone it will be a real treat.
content.location: The next route uphill from Cherty Dancing.

climbs.name: Cherty Dancing
climbs.fa: Luke Bertelsen, Tammy Birkenstock, Matt Martinez,

content.description:
Nobody puts baby in a corner........except at the beginning of this route.  Cherty Dancing begins with two bolts of tricky corner climbing.  Execute the crux of the route relatively low, around bolt two to three, before you begin to dance your way up the balancey and thought provoking slab.

 A wide array of holds: knobs, crimps, jugs, and underclings galore keep things interesting as the climb gradually eases on your way to the chains.

 The limestone at The Farmhouse doesn't get much better than this.  Enjoy!
content.location: Currently the first route one will encounter on the way up the hill into the gutter.

content.description:
These walls are just around the corner from The Bowling Alley Main Wall if you follow the cliff line west. Contouring up the hill there are several black slabs with a handful of very fun featured routes.

 This area is one of the main drainage points from the upper limestone band.  Although not all of the sections of wall will yield climbing you can find some of the coolest limestone features seen at The Farmhouse in this area including tufas, giant threads, pods, pockets, and even some small cave features.

 As with some of the other sectors cholla are PROLIFIC, so be on the lookout for yourself and especially any four-legged friends that might be joining you.
